MUSEUM MILE When Neighborhoods Were Defined by the El
Relatively few elevated trains are left in the city, but neighborhood life along the tracks is being celebrated in ''Under the El'' at the Museum of the City of New York.

Prints and drawings from artists like Philip Reisman, John Sloan and Glenn O. Coleman chart the changing attitudes toward elevated transport and range in style from narrative scenes to Social Realist portraits. Mr. Coleman's ''Election Night'' (above) from 1928, shows life in the cramped, narrow streets underneath the tracks juxtaposed with a celebratory bonfire.

''Under the El, City Life in Twentieth-Century Prints and Drawings;'' through Dec. 3; Museum of the City of New York; 1220 Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street; Wednesday through Saturday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Tuesday 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. for registered groups; Sunday noon to 5 p.m. Closed Mondays; suggested admission contributions: $7 for adults; $4 for students and people over 65; $12 for families; (212) 534-1672.
LOWER EAST SIDE Arts Festival in a Place Known for Its Diversity

The distinct ethnic communities that make up the patchwork of the Lower East Side are represented and portrayed this weekend in the Fifth Annual Lower East Side Festival of the Arts. In the finale of the the festival this evening at the Theater for the New City, the neighborhood's creativity and diversity are highlighted by performing arts organizations, independent artists, poets, politicians, film makers and celebrities coming together (some of whom are shown below).

Lower East Side Festival of the Arts; ends today; Theater for the New City, 155 First Avenue at Tenth Street; poetry 5 p.m. to 7 p.m., Cabaret Theater; performances 6 p.m. Johnson Theater, 8 p.m. Cabaret Theater; free; (212) 254-1109.
BROOKLYN WATERFRONT Dark Chamber, Odd Sounds And Really Big Heads

Six disembodied heads will be projected onto 20-by-15-foot video screens as part of ''NoiseGate,'' a multimedia experience taken by Creative Time to the Brooklyn anchorage of the Brooklyn Bridge, opening Thursday. Two Austrian artists, Kurt Hentschlager and Ulf Langheinrich, collectively known as Granular Synthesis, will add sound to the work with sonic pulses. The bridge's natural sounds are incorporated as well.
On Thursdays in June, electronic composers will collaborate live with Granular Synthesis for new sounds.
''Noise Gate,'' Thursday through June 25; Thursday and Friday 3 p.m. to 8 p.m., Saturday and Sunday 1 p.m. to 6 p.m.; inside Brooklyn Bridge Anchorage, Cadman Plaza West; free; 212-206-6674 ext. 251.

MULTICULTURALISM -- The Kingsbridge Heights Community Center in the Bronx will celebrate its 25th anniversary on Saturday with a multicultural festival with ethnic foods, arts and crafts, a participatory cultural exhibit and live entertainment; 3101 Kingsbridge Terrace between Summit Place and Perot Street; 10 a.m. to 3 p.m.; free; (718) 884-0700.

ONCE UPON A . . . -- Tales of faraway lands, fairy kingdoms and magical musicians, for children 5 through 9, will be read and told at the Henry Hudson Playground in the Bronx next Sunday; Palisade Avenue, Kappock Street and Independence Avenue; 10 a.m.; free; (212) 360-8290.
LOOKING BACK -- Kimiko Hahn, award-winning poet, will conduct a creative writing workshop on memories; Wednesday, East Elmhurst Branch Library; 95-06 Astoria Boulevard, Queens; free; (718) 424-2619.
